There is a program, 'imgSeek', which creates a 'fingerprint' or
'signature'=
 structure that is approximately 128x128 elements.  That's
16,384, which is=
 a LOT of inputs.  Here is what I had in mind, though:

Suppose I have X nu=
mber of images that are all tagged 'rose'.  There
are thousands of other im=
ages that are NOT tagged 'rose'.  Evolve (or
even use backpropagation to tr=
ain) a network to determine the
characteristics that define the 'rose' tag.=
  Then, when future images
are received, they are compared to the 'rose' ta=
g network to determine
the likelihood that the image should have that tag a=
pplied to it.  I
believe there has already been done a fair amount of work =
of that
kind, and it has demonstrated a fair amount of success.

Suppose I =
have image A and image B.  When asked, the user says that A
is better than =
B.  Repeat for thousands of combinations of images. 
Use the signatures of =
those two images as the inputs (yeah, 32,767
inputs) and try to output a nu=
mber between 0 and 1 to indicate which
image is 'better'.  Use this network=
 as a pre-screen for the quality
or likability of images.

Now, since it is=
 such a simple task, a simple classifier in both
cases, could it be that th=
e large number of inputs will still be
manageable?  Or would that be a real=
ly bad idea?  Any tips or
suggestions, thoughts, advice, whatever, would be=
 appreciated.

-- John
